Cats crush Colonels at both ends of court

Towns leads Kentucky with 19 points in rout.

Cats crush Colonels at both ends of court

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 9:36 p.m. EST December 7, 2014

Kentucky forward Karl-Anthony Towns, dunks in the first half. The University of Kentucky Men's Basketball team hosted Eastern Kentucky University, Sunday, Dec. 07, 2014 at Rupp Arena in Lexington. Photo by Jonathan Palmer, Special to the CJ(Photo: Jonathan Palmer)

CONNECT 7 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. It was not a letdown but a beatdown by the top-ranked University of Kentucky basketball team Sunday night at Rupp Arena. After surviving a slugfest with Texas less than 48 hours earlier, the Wildcats were not caught napping against an Eastern Kentucky team with a pesky defense and penchant for the deep ball.

Instead of being bothered by the Colonels' four-guard lineup, which ranks top-three nationally in steals and 3-point attempts, Kentucky swatted them away like pests and rolled to an 82-49 rout. The Wildcats, who had a collective 17 inches of height advantage on EKU's starters, blocked 11 shots and the Colonels made only 18.

Game Rewind | UK preserves streak, beats EKU

MORE: UK women rally to beat U of L

Kentucky (9-0) held EKU (4-3) to 17.1 percent shooting in the first half including just 2 of 17 from 3-point range and coughed up only seven turnovers before the break to seize control quickly. UK scored 11 of 13 points to start the game and 15 straight to end the first half for a 41-14 lead after 20 minutes.

Freshmen Karl-Anthony Towns and Trey Lyles led the way. Towns had 19 points, nine rebounds and four blocks 23 minutes. The 6-foot-10 Lyles, who showed off his unusual perimeter skills with jump shots and driving buckets, had 10 points and 10 boards in 22 minutes.

Junior Willie Cauley-Stein (11) and sophomore Marcus Lee (10) both scored in double figures, while point guards Andrew Harrison and Dominique Hawkins had six assists apiece. The Colonels shot just 26.1 percent for the game and hit only 6 of 30 threes.

    Coach John Calipari played a modified version of his two-platoon system, in part because freshman point guard Tyler Ulis was out sick. Andrew Harrison played with both groups in spurts 11th man Hawkins was the Cats' other point guard and Calipari swapped swingmen Lyles and Alex Poythress at times, also shuffling big men between units.

    The only suspense in the second half was whether Kentucky's 3-point streak would survive. Much like the Texas game, when the Cats missed their first 11 tries before hitting one late, UK bricked 10 in a row Sunday and the crowd was getting antsy.

    Naturally, Aaron Harrison rattled in a contested 3 from the left wing the same spot he hit three clinching 3-pointers during last season's Final Four run with 2:57 remaining. The Wildcats were already up 25, but the Rupp Arena crowd roared because he extended the program's streak to 909 consecutive games with a made 3.

    For good measure, the 6-foot-11 Towns swished another one moments later. Twelfth man Derek Willis entered in the final two minutes and made yet another.

    COURIER-JOURNAL
